info.description:
## LuTime

‚úÖ *Easily get access* to abstract, time themed objects (i.e., time, second, date, year, milisecond) in Python.

### Requirements

 - üêç [Python>=3.7](https://www.python.org/downloads/)

#

### ‚¨áÔ∏è Installation
#### ü™ü Windows:
```bash
pip install LuTime 
```

#### üçé üêß MacOS & Linux:
```bash
pip3 install LuTime
```

#

### ‚òïSimple Demonstration

```python
from LuTime.lutime import get # Importing the get function from the module

current_Time = get('time') # Creating a variable and assigning the time to it
current_Second = get('second') # Creating a variable and assigning the second to it

print(f"The current time is: {current_Time} and the current second is: {current_Second}")
```

#

### üìÉ All 'Time Objects':

####  You can use the first column or second column and it's not case sensitive so it doesn't matter if you type in all capital letters!

| **Long**        	| **Short** 	|
|-----------------	|-----------	|
| **second**      	| **sec**   	|
| **minute**      	| **min**   	|
| **hour**        	| **hr**    	|
| **day**         	| **d**     	|
| **month**       	| **m**     	|
| **year**        	| **yr**    	|
| **date**        	| **N/A**   	|
| **time**        	| **N/A**   	|
| **datetime**    	| **dt**    	|
| **timestamp**   	| **ts**    	|
| **millisecond** 	| **ms**    	|
| **microsecond** 	| **us**    	|
